div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.
Helouan Races.
Our report of these races, having been delayed in transmission, cannot be published to-day.
Guards Dinner.
The annual dinner of the Guards Regiment, which is stationed in Cairo, will be held on the 10th prox.
Grand Hotel, Helouan.
A small dance with the performance of the Bracale orchestra is taking place at the Grand, Hotel, Helouan, on Friday, the 27th inst.
Bourse Holidays.
The Bourses at Alexandria and Cairo will be closed on the 25th and 26th inst. for the Christmas holidays and on New Year, the 1st and 2nd proxo.
The Bibby Line.

Notwithstanding the fact that the Bibby Line did not join the other first class lines in the increase of their fares by 10%, they have decided to allow Egyptian Government Officials a rebate of 10% off the ordinary fares.
Damanhour School.

The Damanhour School prize distribution, wires our correspondent, was held this morning, the Mudir presiding. The Mudir delivered an excellent speech and afterwards distributed monetary awards to the teachers of the kuttabs.
Railway Contract.

The Egyptian Railway Administration has accepted the tender of Messrs Ahmed Rustom, Toussoum and Co. for the supply of 200,000 pine wood sleepers at the cost of 158 and 168 milliemes per sleeper according to the system 7 transport.
Kaseala Cemetery.

A Christian Cemetery has been lately consecrated at Kassala. Father Huber, of the African Mission at Khartoum, celebrated the consecration service. Slatin Pasha, Wilkinson Bey and a large number of the Christian population of Kassala attended the ceremonies.
The Gale.

The heavy seas of the past two days have washed immense quantities of seaweed into the roadway on the new quay, and somewhat damaged the lifebuoys recently erected by the Municipality. Quite an army of workmen are busy this morning clearing the debris.

div.head: The Moore Case.
div.p: The libel actions brought by Mr. Moore, of the P.W D., against "Al Ahram," "Al Lewa," "Les Pyramides," and other local papers will come on for hearing before the Cairo Mixed Court on Monday next. Maitre Carton de Wiart will appear for Mr. Moore.
Coal Imports.

Between January 1 and December 19 1,306,978 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 715,055 tons were Welsh, 162,249 Newcastle, 186,149 Yorkshire, 100,080 Scotch and 143,445 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the imports totalled 1,222,845.
Al Hayat.

We understand that the managing board of Al Hayat intend to delete the word sanatorium from the name by which this popular Helouan hotel is generally known. Sanatorium, indeed, is quite a misnomer, especially in view of the fact that the hotel management makes it a rule not to accept consumptive persons.
Christmas at Mena.

There will be a christmas tree at Mena House on Tuesday afternoon, the 24th inst., at 5 p.m., when the staff choir will sing a series of Christmas Carols as in previous years. Tea will be served for the occasion, and a band will play. After dinner a small dance will be held. No invitations will be sent but all patrons of Mena are cordially invited.
Collection of Autographs.

A fine collection of autographs of which the larger part comes from famous literary men, is possessed by the General Direction of the h Berlitz School. The branches in Alexandria, 12 rue Rosette, and 1 Sharia Kamel, thanks o the large number of notabilities who frequent their classes of whom the satisfaction is unanimous, will soon be in a position to possess an autograph book very interesting for the country of Egypt.
Big Hats in Theatres.

The enormous size of fashionable hats are most inconvenient to playgoers and the management of the Alhambra Theatre at Alexandria has lately issued notices asking its patrons of the fair sex to come to the theatre hatless. Last night at the performance of Fregoli at the Alhambra only about six of the many ladies present wore hats. Mr. Conegliano begs us to thank his lady patrons for their consideration in the matter.

div.head: OUR FOREIGN POLICY.
div.p: NAVAL EXPENDITURE-
THE PERSIAN TROUBLES
POLICY OF NON-INTERFERENCE
(Gazette's Speolal Service.)
London, Friday.

Sir E. Grey, speaking at Berwick last night, said that the German Government were embarking on a very large naval programme. "I have no complaint to make of that," he said in the course of his speech, "but at the same time if other nations increase their navies we shall have to increase ours. There is no need for us to be rushed into naval expenditure at the present moment as our position is perfectly secure for one year or two, but if our neigh- bours increase their naval expenditure largely it will not be possible for us to continue the reduction of ours."

Speaking of Persia, Sir E. Grey said that had it not been for the Anglo-Russian convention it would have been a great temptation to Russia or England to interfere. So long as Persia does not display any anti-foreign feeling, foreign nations should abstain from interference.
A telegram from Teheran says that matters there are no worse. Russia and England will act in concert where it is necessary. A new cabinet has been formed with Nizam es Sultaneh as Premier.

div.head: LADY GORST "AT HOME"
div.p: The first dance of the season at the British Agency took place on Thursday when Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst were at home to some three hundred guests between the hours of 10 and 1 o'clock. The ball room was crowded throughout the evening, the non-dancers finding plenty of accomodation in the adjoining drawing rooms amid luxurious surroundings enhanced by beautiful flowers and groups of feathery foliage. Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst received their guests at the entrance of the reception rooms, and though the occasion was more or less an informal one all the notabilities of Cairo society were present, and many beautiful toilettes and handsome uniforms were to be seen, Owing to the numbers and the congestion in the ball room it was almost an impossibility after the dancing commenced to see who was present: hence any attempt to give a list of the guests is bound to be inadequate. But among those noticed during the evening were: Mr. Machell and Lady Valda Machell, the Count von Bernstorff and Miss Bernstorff, Mons: de Willebois and Mlles. de Willebois, Sir Reginald and Lady Oakes, Sir John and Lady Rogers, Lord Edward Cecil, Sir William Willeocks, Sir Horace and Lady Pinching. div.head: DRUCE DRAMA.
div.p: GRAVE TO BE OPENED.
(Gazette's Special Service).
LONDON, Saturday.
The Druce grave is to be opened after Christmas.

From the above telegram it is to be presumed that the Home Office has given the neces sary permission for this important step in the history of the great claim to the Portland Estates. Mrs. Anna Druce's action disclosed the onrious circumstance that there is no legal process known to English law by which the Druce vault and coffin can be opened. The vault is Mr. Herbert Druce's property, and yet even he could not open his father's coffin with- out incurring the liability of prosecution. The Home Office can only order the exhumation of a body upon the suspicion that the deceased had been the victim of foul play. It is clear that if there is any key to the coffin at all, Mr, Herbert Druce holds it; and it remains to be seen whether he will turn it in consequence of any course which the present perjury prosecution may take. If, however, the claimant proved that Mr. T. C. Druce did not die in 1864, but was, in fact, alive until 1879, he would yet have to establish his principal contention-that Mr T. C Druce was indeed the Duke of Port land. An action for the recovery of the estates which he claims would be heard in the King's Bench Division; an application for the declaration of his title to the property would be assigned to the Chancery Division.

The latter's responsibility was the greater as having a more extensive area and greater population.

div.head: DISCOVERY OF A VANDYCK
div.p: (Gazette's special service.)

London, Saturday. It is reported that an authentic canvas by Vandyck has been found in the Flemish village Waesmunster. It was discovered among old stuff from a convent which was sold by auction for fourpence.

div.head: PORT SAID COAL STRIKE
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).
Port Said, Friday.

As I wired you this morning the bunkering Arabe have come out on strike. The 8.S. "Tydens" which came out of the Canal about 5.30 yesterday evening was the first vessel the strikers refused to coal; she was obliged to take her bunkers in with her own crew, and up to the time of writing she is still bunkering. Coaling operations to-day have been con- ducted entirely by the ships' own crews and in all cases the work has been slow, but the strikers have not interfered in any way. The French 8.8 "Malte" arrived here at 4 p.m. to-day and intended taking two thousand tons of coal, but upon hearing of the strike, a wire was sent to Paris asking for instructions. It is expected that she will proceed to Aden and take her bunkers there.

Several strikers collected on the quay this morning, but they were not allowed to loaf about. Owing to the disturbances which occurred during the last strike the Port police are making every effort to prevent them from congregating around the harbour.

Half a company of mounted police and a large draft of foot police arrived here early, this morning from Cairo and are encamped at the back of the Governor's residence; this addition to our force should be strong enough to maintain order.

div.head: A SENSATIONAL MURDER
div.p: ALEXANDRIAN ADVOCATE KILLED
THE ASSASSIN A CLIENT

Yesterday afternoon at 4.30 o'clock an Italian advocate of the name of Volpini, was murdered in his chambers in Mohamed Aly square, Alexandria, by one of his clients Salvatore Massimiliano, an Italian carpenter. The murdered man was thirty-three years of age and was formerly editor of an Italian daily paper here, "Il Corrieri Egiziano," now defunct. He was the nephew of the late Roman Catholic Archbishop at Alexandria, Monsignor Gaudenzid Bonfigli. The murderer is a well-built man, in the prime of life, and does not present any criminal characteristics. He stabbed Volpini, after a short altercation, repeatedly with a blade from a swordstick and his victim expired immediately. The advocate's room presented ghastly spectacle, the floor being covered with blood. The murderer was at once arrested and conducted to the Menshieh Caracol, where he gave a statement of the deed and of the reasons which led up to it. He did not show any remorse, but on the contrary declared that he was pleased at having killed Volpini.
THE MURDERER'S STORY.

The story told by Massimiliano was to the following effect. Four years ago he had been shot at and wounded by some Bedouins in the Mariout district. He wanted to take legal action and he entrusted the case to Mr. Volpini. Subsequently he went to Constantinople, as he had some work there and he wrote three letters to the lawyer on the subject of his case. The latter did not reply for some time, but at last a letter came from him, asking Massi- miliano for money to proceed with the case. Massimiliano threw up his job at Constantinople and came to Alexandria under the impression that at last his case was nearing its end. He gave Volpini money to bring it to successful conclusion. He then went to the Sudan as he found a job at Khartoum. While there he received a communication from Volpini, which inspired him with such hope as to the case being soon ended, that he threw up his work and returned to Alexandria. Here he found that the law's delays were interminable. Volpini kept procrastinating and the conclusion of the case seemed as far off as ever. Massimiliano's situation became deplorable. He could find no work at Alexandria and for three months he slept on the quays. Yesterday he determined to take the case out of Volpini's hands and entrust it to another lawyer. He went up to his chambers with a friend, Balthazar Felice, and there he asked Volpini to give up all the documents connected with the case as he was worn out with waiting. The lawyer gave him the documents, but refused to hand him the medical certificate, which was essential to his case. Hot words ensued and the lawyer ordered his old client to get out of the room. The latter expostulated and raised his stick and then Volpini drew a revolver. Massimiliano at once drew out the poignard and stabbed the lawyer many times with fatal effect. Volpini expired in the arms of one of his employés, while Massimiliano was immediately arrested by a clerk of the office and handed over to the police.
ANOTHER VERSION.

Another version is given us by Volpini's partner, who was seated in the same room behind a partition. Our informant has no knowledge of the case which led up to the murder as he had only joined Volpini lately. He states that about four o'clock Felice entered Volpini's office and that he was followed a few minutes afterwards by Massimiliano. After a few minutes' conversation our informant's attention was attracted by noise and he rushed to the other compartment of the room where he saw Massimiliano stab Volpini in the shoulder. He seized hold of Massimiliano and shouted for the boab's assistance, and the murderer attempted to stab him in the abdomen. Massimiliano, he asserts, attempted to escape, but was held until the arrival of the police by our informant and a gentleman who joined him. He asserts that Volpini drew no revolver and that the revolver, which was found on the floor, had been brought to the office that afternoon by the murdered man in order to have it repaired.
Great sympathy is expressed with the murdered man's widow, whose married life of three months has been brought to so cruel termination.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. "Corsican Prince" with general cargo left Malta on the 20th inst. and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Monday evening. The S.S. "Roman Prince" with passengers and general cargo left Antwerp on the 15th inst. and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 2nd January.

The S.S. "Merchant Prince" left London on the 18th inst. and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 4th January. The German training ship "Stein" which ar rived here yesterday will remain in harbour until January 2nd. The "Freyer" sails this afternoon for Beyrout.

div.head: EGYPTIAN POLITICS
div.p: THE REPUBLICAN PARTY.
The formation of the new Republican Party in Egypt is attracting some attention in London as the following paragraph from an article in "The Globe" will show:-

The "Republic of Egypt" is a new idea in politics, but though the name has a strange air, and sounds more strangely still, it is none the less the watchword of a new party, who are styl ing themselves Republican Nationalists. Their manifesto is not yet proclaimed, but it is being drawn up, apparently at secret conclaves held in one or another of the international clubs in Cairo. Meanwhile, those who might fear that the rising Republicans intend emulating the deeds of the Mountain, or of Robespierre, are reassured by a moving spirit of the new Republic

In a letter to the Press, he states that the aims of the party will be to diffuse in Egypt the ideal of an Egyptian Republic. A programme is at present under discussion When ready it will be submitted to public judgment Without disclosing details as to the methods proposed for dealing with the British occupation, together with the Khedivial dynasty, the writer declares in brief that Republican independence and au tonomy will be formulated. A newspaper will be founded to propagate Republican doctrines. The results of the first general meeting of the party, soon to be held, will be made known before the end of December. It is not surprising that out of the welter of Egyptian political parties some such extreme as this ideal Republic should emerge.
THE REFORM PARTY.

The Coptic Organ, "Al Watan" is very vigorous in its criticism of the new party, officially entitled the Constitutional Reform League, whose policy and constitution was the subject of a detailed account in yesterday's issue. The organ of the Copts remarks:-

The Reform Party, headed by Sheik Ali Youssef of "Al-Moayad," is a new creation, the result of a schism in the Nationalist camp for purely personal motives. Some observers even think that the schism was a premeditated arrangement inspired by quarters that feared a coming danger and thought that a temporary show of moderation may ward off the said danger. According to these observers the whole lot of Moderates represented by "Al-Garida" and Reformists following "Al-Moayad" were brought to existence by the same power and the same cause. But this moderation of "Al-Moayad" is the most monstrous fraud of our political world, as the angel of moderation is no other than the most venomous agitator and extreme Nationalists who actually founded the party of Extremists and gave its leaders a start in life. Up to a very recent date the moderate Sheikh was a most violent enemy of reform. Who can believe his belated moderation now?
THE LIBERAL PARTY.

It has been stated that Mohamed Bey Wahid, the leader of the Egyptian Liberal Party, is engaged in the constitution of the Nationalist Republican Party Mohamed Bey Wahid has issued a formal contradiction to these statements, as his efforts in the world of Egyptian politics are solely enlisted on behalf of the Liberal Party.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE-
div.p: DEBUT OF FREGOLI.

Last night Fregoli, the world-famous quickchange artiste and ventriloquist, made his début at the Alhambra theatre, Alexandria. The success with which he met was certainly immense, and he was most heartily applauded by a very well filled house. Nor was the enthusiasm of the audience misplaced, for Fregoli is a genius such as Egypt is quite unaccustomed to. His changes of character were quite marvellous, and he so staged his various items as to give the best possible effects and hide from the audience those lightening changes which are necessary for the representation of several characters by one man. In male and female characters alike he was quite natural, and in the latter parts his voice was wonderfully true to the sex. In commenting upon his bistrionic abilities it would be impossible to exaggerate his cleverness in the branch which he has adopted, and we genuinely advise all our readers to seize the opportunity of seeing his performance during the fortnight that he will be in Alexandria. Fregoli's one act pieces were performed, in an altogether marvellous manner, and in the second part of his programme he gave us a variety show equal to almost any café chantant performance, his representations of various well-known composers conducting their own works being exceptionally excellent, while the weird effects which he produced in his serpentine dance were both extraordinary and artistic.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA'S HOUSING PROBLEM.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir,-I have frequently seen comments in your columns anent ourlethargie Municipality, which you have more than once taken to task for the continued shelving of the economie houses proposals. The members of the Municipality and the many readers of your widespread paper will doubtless be interested to learn what the Servian Government is doing for its poor and needy subjects. The Belgrade newspaper "Lo Srbskilist" announces the fol lowing grants:-280,000 frs. for the con- struction of economic houses; 100,000 frs. for the construction of an hospital; 50,000 frs. for public baths; and 50.000 frs. for the assistance of the unemployed; i.e. a total grant of 580,000 frs. (approximately LE. 23,200) for the alleviation of poverty. And yet, though poverty in Alexandria is daily becoming more pro minent owing to the rich landlord having the power to exorbitantly increase his rental charges year by year, the members of our Municipality are content to twiddle their thumbs, and grant-smiles of sympathy. Are we to be compelled to adopt the drastic mea- sures of a tenants' strike ?
Yours etc.

div.head: MEETING OF CLERGY IN CAIRO.
div.p: Yesterday the Clergy of the Anglican Archdeaconry in Egypt met in Cairo. The proceedings commenced with a celebration of the Holy Communion in All Saints' Church. The Mr. J. H. Molesworth, assisted by the Rev. J. T. Burns, officiated. A devotional address was givin by the Archdeacon. After breakfast in the Church House, kindly provided by the Chaplain of All Saints, the Clergy reassembled for Morning Prayer at 11 am, when a second address was given, in which the Archdeacon, after paying a tribute of respect to the memory of four Clergy in this Bishopric, who have died during the present year, Lave an account of the work which is being done by the Church of England in Egypt at the present time. After the service the Clergy assembled in the Church House for a short conference

div.head: A. R. M. D. S.
div.p: A concert will be given at the Savoy Palace Hotel, Alexandria, on Friday, January 8, 1908, by the Alexandria and Ramleh Amateur Musical and Dramatic Society, to which H.E Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria, has most kindly consented to extend his pa tronage. All members are invited to attend the concert, and to introduce non-members, who will be charged a nominal entrance of P.T. 10. Persons desirous of joining the Society should apply at once to the Hou Bec. c/o "The Egypt ian Gasetta." Subscriptions should be paid at an early date to Mr. H. C. Moss, Hon. Treasurer, c/o Mosers R. J. Moss and Co, EV. The yearly embeoription for individual members is P.T. 40 and for a family (four) membership P.T. 100.

Une demande analogue avait déja «té formulée l'année dernié¢re, mais nayant pas été faite dans les delais preacrits per les statuts, elle avait été rejetée.

La Cour Supréme du Consulat Britannique s'est prononcée lundi sur les dewx appels de la Boursesand Banking contre les jugements du tribunal consulaire do 20 éeoald. Bille a rejeté les deux appels et condamné la société aux frais. Cesarréts sont trés importants parce de remettre a plus tard, qu'ils déclarent justiciable da tribunal consv- laire britannique toute société constituée sous pe régime anglais, que son conseil d'adminie- {tration soit composé d'étrangers ov non. En l'espéce la Cour Supréme a déclaré que, con- trairement aux prétentions de la Bourse and Banking, le tribunal consulaireétait compétent pour juger du remplacement du liquidateur actuel par un autre nommé par le tribunal ; elle a,de plus, condamné la Société 4 délivrer les titres sans formule sp'ciale. Grice 4 cet arrét, les actionnaires peuvent présenter les titres A leurs agents et les obliger 4 régler leur compte on, en cas de refus,les poursuivre devant les tribunaux. Un jagement do tribnnal con- eulaire est attenda a bref délai dans une affaire de ce genre et il est probable qu'il servira de régle pour les cas analogues.

div.head: The Cotton Market.
div.p: Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report
Liverpool, December 12.

Egyptian Cotton. There has been a fair demand on the Spot during the past week, with a tendency for the finer qualities to hardon. The quotations are unchanged except Good Brown which is advanced to, and Good and Fine Upperst plb

Patares have been in rather better demand, and the following are the latest quotations :Dec. 10.2 Mar. 9.60 June 9.58 Sept. 9.55 Jan. 9.69 Apr. 9.58 July 9.57 Oct. 9.53 Feb. 9.69 May 9.58 Aug. 9.56 Nov. 9.50

Amorican Futures. The market this week bas boon active both on the spot and for Paturo delivery. There have been frequent and sharp fluctuations, but today's closing values are very little changed from those of last Thursday. The anxiously awaited Ginners' roport, and that of the Agricultural Bureau have come and gone, and left as much about the same, and as much puzzled as ever.

It is hard to reconcile the Ginners' 8,338,000 and the Bureau Crop estimate of 11,678,000, but that the Crop is for short of last year's total there can no longer be any doubt ; to what extent however, will not be decided, we foar, for some time to come.

Plantors are holding their cotton for high prioos, and although later we may find that consumors will take less than last season, at present there is a large and sustained demand for the actual cotton, and apparently present values are not checking it.

The latest quotations are, delivery :December 8.904 Mar./Apl. 5.94 July/Aug. 6.93) Dec./Jan. 6.90) April/May 6.914 Aug/Sept. 5.83) Jan. (Pob. 5.92) May June 6.95, Sept./Oot. 6.71 Feb./Mar. 6,93; June/July 6.96 Oot./Nov. 6.601

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6. Purchasers should see that the word 'THERAPION' appears on British Government Stamp (in white letters on a red ground) affixed to every package by order of His Majesty's Hon. Commissioners, and without which it is a forgery.
